request_pathways.name: Authorization for Release of Protected Health Information

forms.document_type: ROI authorization form (Cincinnati region, Rev 1/19, text-layer version)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients use a generic HIPAA authorization form that lists 'Self' as the first recipient option, with MyChart and Swellbox online portal as alternative digital pathways.

red_flags: Photo ID required at time of request — may exclude patients without government-issued identification
Currently linked form (form-2) is an image-only scan replacing a previously functional text-layer PDF — accessibility regression
bright_spots: Self is the first recipient checkbox option, with personal use as the default purpose
Electronic format (PDF/CD) is the default if patient does not specify
MyChart delivery listed as a form option alongside mail, fax, and email
Swellbox/Datavant online portal available as a fully digital alternative
Spanish-language version of the form available
Explicit citation of HIPAA § 164.524 (individual right of access)

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation or a simple search — the centralized medical records page was quickly located via web search, though the better text-layer form (form-1) is no longer directly linked.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Usable digitally with workarounds — the primary linked PDF is an image-only scan requiring print-and-handwrite, but fax submission is available and the Swellbox online portal provides an alternative digital pathway; neither PDF form has fillable fields.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor clarity issues — single-page form with logical flow, granular record-type checkboxes, and clear instructions, though the legal disclosure section is densely packed and the 'standard two years' default could confuse patients.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the generic HIPAA authorization form serves both patient self-access and third-party release without differentiation, though 'Self' as the first recipient option and personal-use default partially mitigate this.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities but nothing that would materially impede a patient — includes clear revocation rights and voluntary authorization language, but the photo ID requirement and vague fee disclosure ('there may be a charge') are minor concerns.

overall.summary: Mercy Health - Fairfield Hospital offers a functional but unexceptional records request experience: easy to find with multiple pathways including an online portal, but reliant on a generic authorization form with no fillable fields and a troubling regression to an image-scan PDF as the primary linked document.
